The aim of the poet throughout is not so much purely scientific as practica! and moral His main object, as he tells us again and again, is to free men's minds from the yoke of superstitious fears by dis-

playing to them the aspect and the laws ol nature3 and this is why he argues with such passionate eamestness against the immortality of the soul and the interierence os the gods in human affairs. Thus the purpose of the fifth book is to show that the world and all that it contains were not created by divine power, and that all progress is the result of natural experience, not os divine guidance. And on the whole it appears that Lucretius lived long enough to complete in out· line tho whole task he had set before himself, though the latter partos the poem is sar from complete in artistic finish and arrangement of materials.

With regard to the diction and metre os the poem, Lucretius ‘deliberately adopted a style which must have seemed archaic to his contemporaries. This may be seen by comparing the De Rerum Natura with the Peleus and Thetis os Catullus, which was certainly written at nearly the same time. Just as Greek epic verse continued to the end to imitate the forms and vocabulary ol Homer, so Lucretius thought fit to take sor his model the Annales of Ennius, the only great epic which 'the language possessed, though two centuries had passed since it was written. At the beginning of his own poem he makes honourable mention of Ennius1, and constantly imitates even the few hundred lines os fragments which we possess lt is pro· bable too that his archaism was intended as a protest against the tendency os contemporary Latin literature For just at this time there was great literary activity among the Romans.
